body:
The build time code has always been a horrible mess.  The parameters for calculating the actual build time are spread over four(!) different traits and an `Actor` extension method.

I think you have the right idea, but propose taking it further.  We should remove the `CustomBuildTimeValue` trait, the `CustomBuildTimeExts` class, `ProductionQueueInfo.BuildSpeed`, and define the following on `Buildable`:

``` csharp
[Desc("Base build time (-1 indicates use the unit's Value)")
public readonly int BuildDuration = -1;

[Desc("Percentage modifier to apply to the build duration")]
public readonly int BuildDurationModifier = 40;
```

This gives you the same configuration, but with all the important things (except the actor value) in one place.

I don't understand why should this deprecate `ProductionQueueInfo.BuildSpeed` tbh. I'll look into the rest tomorrow, but these two aren't interchangeable to me - there might be cases where an actor might want to be trained in two queues and one might be a slower queue than the other (individual-queue-based starport vs war factory f. e.).
Starport vs war factory use two different actor types with a special hack for group select.

I'm aware. Which is why I said individual-queue-based.

What I meant is that there might be cases, when a modder might want to have a limited-availability-but-faster queue (buildimited/expensive queue provider) and a slower-but-common queue (cheaper/nonbuildlimited queue provider) running along. without cloning each unit between all the queues - something the D2k starport does atm.
Sure, but that use case is rare / edge-casey enough that it is cleaner for that specific case to define new inherited actors instead having an extra redundant parameter for all actors in all mods.
Actually, we already do this in the d2k starport. https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/bleed/mods/d2k/rules/player.yaml#L42
Indeed, but it could just as easily be defined as an additional override on the already-overriden `Buildable` trait for each starport actor.
I assume you want the modifier adjust the fixed value as well then? Because the D2K vehicles also rely on fixed buildtimes as well.

Yes – the idea is to reduce the current configuration mess down to two parameters (with one having a magic value to say "use this third parameter") that work consistently across all configuration setups.

I'm still against this, though, because YR also had the queue-based buildspeed multiplier and the unit-based-buildspeed multiplier this PR intends to introduce - the WW games before that only had queue-based buildspeed.

And honestly, I can't see what's messy in that setup.

Right now we have this situation (assuming the non-classic production queue – yet another factor is included for the production speedup on the classic version):

No custom build time:

``` csharp
duration = 1500 * Valued.Cost * ProductionQueue.BuildSpeed / 100000;

CustomBuildTime.Value > 0 (CustomBuildTime.Multiplier is completely ignored!)
duration = CustomBuildTime.Value * ProductionQueue.BuildSpeed / 100;

CustomBuildTime.Value <= 0 (CustomBuildTime.Value is completely ignored!)
duration = 1500 * Valued.Cost * CustomBuildTime.Multiplier * ProductionQueue.BuildSpeed / 10000000;
```

This is needlessly complicated and does not solve any problems that can't be covered by:

``` csharp
duration = (Buildable.BuildDuration OR Valued.Cost) * Buildable.BuildDurationModifier / 100
```

plus additional actor types (which already exist for our one mod that uses this feature) if you want to have actors with different build times on different queues.

I forgot about that factor of 1.5, so the default `BuildDurationModifier` would be `60` instead of `40`.

This is nicer for modders because `BuildDuration` can be interpreted as "calculate the build duration as if the actor cost this much".  This is much more accessible than an arbitrary number that is related to the cost by a modifier that you have to dig through the source code to work out.
Note for people using email notifications: my original comment had a bunch of code typos which have been corrected.

I understand and I intend to simplify that constant. However, I will not shoot myself in the leg by removing a feature I rely on in my own PR.

Right now, I'm heavily relying on `ProductionQueueInfo.BuildSpeed` on infantry, because I rely on really cheap and slower trained infantry, to downplay zergspam tactics. (I'm also using it to speed up the vehicle training a bit for this same reason.) However, I'm running into an issue that since high-tier units require more money, they end up being trained too slow so that lowtier stuff can easily outspam them. Since this is a global issue, I thought that introducing a tier-based buildspeed bonus would counter that issue of mine.

With your solution, I cannot fulfill my original aim of expanding my already-established techlevel template with the buildspeed bonuses from the techlevel, and would force me to introduce another 16 templates for my actors to get their buildspeed from (since atm I have 4 distinct unit queues and 4 techlevels and I plan to have more queues even) which I'm not a fan of, personally.

I don't want to kill what is otherwise a good cleanup over a philosophical point, so i'll back off on the `BuildSpeed` removal.

Can you please implement the other changes, so that we have a consistent calculation of

```
duration = (Buildable.BuildDuration OR Valued.Cost) * Buildable.BuildDurationModifier * ProductionQueue.BuildSpeed / 10000;
```

?  I think it would be best to fold the constants into `BuildDurationModifier` as I outlined above, and then change `ProductionQueue.BuildSpeed` to a `ProductionQueue.BuildModifier` defaulting to 100.  This then separates the concerns of cost from production modifiers.
Sure, I'll do that tomorrow.
Updated.

Updated.

Right now, the upgrade rules shouldn't change the status of the mods. I don't think there is a way to completely look up the proper queue speed multiplier from the unit in `UpgradeRules`, but if you think outputting a warning is enough, I'll do it.
Yes, i agree that printing a warning and doing a manual fixup is the best approach.
Updated.
Needs a rebase.
Rebased.
Rebased again.
Rebased and updated.
Needs a rebase again.

Sorry, I know it's nasty...
The lua method doesn't seem to work for TD.

How did you tested this on TD?

``` diff
--- a/mods/cnc/rules/structures.yaml
+++ b/mods/cnc/rules/structures.yaml
@@ -28,6 +28,7 @@ FACT:
        LowPowerSlowdown: 2
        QueuedAudio: Building
        ReadyAudio: ConstructionComplete
+       BuildDurationModifier: 200 #default 100
    ProductionQueue@NodBuilding:
        Type: Building.Nod
        Factions: nod
@@ -35,6 +36,7 @@ FACT:
        LowPowerSlowdown: 2
        QueuedAudio: Building
        ReadyAudio: ConstructionComplete
+       BuildDurationModifier: 200 #default 100
    ProductionQueue@GDIDefense:
        Type: Defence.GDI
        Factions: gdi
@@ -42,6 +44,7 @@ FACT:
        LowPowerSlowdown: 3
        QueuedAudio: Building
        ReadyAudio: ConstructionComplete
+       BuildDurationModifier: 200 #default 100
    ProductionQueue@NodDefense:
        Type: Defence.Nod
        Factions: nod
@@ -49,6 +52,7 @@ FACT:
        LowPowerSlowdown: 3
        QueuedAudio: Building
        ReadyAudio: ConstructionComplete
+       BuildDurationModifier: 200 #default 100
    BaseBuilding:
    ProductionBar@BuildingGDI:
        ProductionType: Building.GDI
@@ -103,6 +107,7 @@ NUKE:
        BuildPaletteOrder: 10
        Prerequisites: fact
        Queue: Building.GDI, Building.Nod
+       BuildDurationModifier: 40 #default 60
    Building:
        Footprint: xx xx
        Dimensions: 2,2
diff --git a/OpenRA.Mods.Common/Scripting/Global/ActorGlobal.cs b/OpenRA.Mods.Common/Scripting/Global/ActorGlobal.cs
index 8ebdf81..d404ca2 100644
--- a/OpenRA.Mods.Common/Scripting/Global/ActorGlobal.cs
+++ b/OpenRA.Mods.Common/Scripting/Global/ActorGlobal.cs
@@ -109,6 +112,9 @@ public int BuildTime(string type, string producer = null)
            }
            time = time * bi.BuildDurationModifier * pbi / 10000;
+
+           Game.Debug("{0} has a build time of {1}.", type, time);
+
            return time;
        }
```

returns me 400 for the power plant with the yaml changes and 300 without in Nod07a.
Rebased, updated.
I get `Eluant.LuaException: No actors can produce actor 'e1'!` when trying `Media.DisplayMessage("e " .. Actor.BuildTime("e1"))` on gdi01.
Fixed.
Rebased.
